abstract.para: This document is intended for systems administrators interested in configuring their service to use the API Validation component of the &PRODEXPAND;.

chapter.title: About This Document
chapter.para: The purpose of this handbook is to facilitate deployment of &PRODNAME;'s API Validation component. This handbook is not a tutorial. It provides basic information that will help you understand and deploy this &PRODNAME; component, but you must adapt this information to suit your own configuration.
This handbook is focused on one &PRODNAME; component. Other &PRODNAME; components are documented in companion handbooks.

chapter.title: Introduction to the API Validation Component of &PRODNAME;
chapter.para: API validation examines an API request and confirms that it is constructed correctly before forwarding it to its destination.

To use &PRODNAME; for API validation, you must add the API validation component as a filter in your &PRODNAME; configuration. You can learn more about customizing your &PRODNAME; configuration by reading the Repose Deployment Handbook and by examining a basic system model configuration in GitHub.

To understand the &PRODNAME; API validation filter, you should understand several related concepts:
Application Programming Interface (API)
Web Application Description Language (WADL)
XML Schema Definition (XSD)
stylesheets

An Application Programming Interface (API) can be written in several alternative styles, notably Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP) and REpresentational State Transfer (REST). &PRODNAME;, the &PRODEXPAND;, is designed to work with REST APIs only.
You can describe a REST API using Web Application Description Language (WADL); a description written in WADL is also referred to as a WADL. A WADL document is a specialized XML document.

A WADL provides a machine-readable description of an HTTP-based application. For an introduction to WADL, read Web Application Description Language. For a discussion of how WADL can be used for API validation, read the "Background" section of Using XProc, XSLT 2.0, and XSD 1.1 to validate RESTful services.

An XSD formally describes the elements in an XML document such as a WADL. A WADL describes valid requests for an API; an XSD describes valid elements within a WADL. For example, a WADL may describe a valid parameter as <param name="userId" type="xsd:string" style="template" required="true"/>. In this case, type="xsd:string" indicates that this parameter is a string, however string is defined in the XSDs available to that WADL. In the same WADL,
<application xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <grammars> <include href="../xsd/mytesting.xsd"/> </grammars> </application>
identifies two XSDs as descriptions of the elements within the WADL: http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema is a standard XSD, available to everyone; ../xsd/mytesting.xsd is a special-purpose XSD, defining non-standard elements that are valid within this WADL.
&PRODNAME; uses XSD 1.1. A good tutorial on XSD 1.1, including a comparison of XSD 1.1 and XSD 1.0, is at http://www.xfront.com/xml-schema-1-1/.

To validate a request, the API validation filter component compares the current request to a previously-established description of a valid request. That description is based on one or more WADLs and one or more XSDs.

For example, if an authentication service requires a username in the URI for all valid requests, that requirement is defined in the authentication service's WADL and the &PRODNAME; API validation component is configured to compare requests to that WADL. With the &PRODNAME; API validation component in the filter stack, authentication requests that do not include a username are rejected before reaching the authentication service. This protects the authentication service from the workload of identifying and rejecting invalid requests. It also allows the developers of the authentication service to focus on developing that service's core features rather than on general-purpose features such as validation. In addition, the validation process can be configured so that, when a request is rejected, that rejection response can provide detailed information describing what was unacceptable about the request.

tip.para:
The API validation component is designed somewhat similarly to the translation component; one or the other may be ideal for your purpose.
To determine whether an API request is constructed correctly, use the API validation component.
To alter an invalid request so that it becomes a valid API request, use the translation component.
You can read about the translation component at
http://wiki.openrepose.org/display/REPOSE/Translation.
API validation processing is controlled by validator.cfg.xml; to change your validation configuration, edit validator.cfg.xml. You can see an annotated example of validator.cfg.xml in .

chapter.title: Configuration

tip.para: Before attempting to customize your validation configuration and its stylesheets, familiarize yourself with the basic &PRODNAME; concepts and deployment methods in our Getting Started document.

chapter.para: The API validation component obtains its configuration, including its API endpoint, from a file named validator.cfg.xml. We have included an annotated example of a valid validator.cfg.xml in this chapter.
To change your validation configuration, edit validator.cfg.xml at any time.

The validation component uses your validation configuration to recognize whether an API request is valid. If an API request is not valid, the validation component handles it as specified in your response messaging configuration at response-messaging.cfg.xml.

section.title: Customizing a Validation Configuration
section.para: Your validation configuration in validator.cfg.xml will resemble the following example:
Key elements of the preceding example are labeled with callouts and explained below:

callout.para: Multiple validators can be defined within this <validators> wrapper.
When set to true, validation is attempted for the X-Roles header; validation is attempted for every match until one is valid.
Otherwise, validation is attempted for the X-Roles header and validation is attempted for only the first match.
If no matches are found, only the validator which specifies default="true" is used.
If matches are found but none of them are valid, only the validator which specifies default="true" is used.
One validator is defined within this <validator> wrapper.

When multiple roles are assigned, match this validator to requests according to the X-Roles header with the highest quality value. Roles are assigned quality values so that preference does not depend on the order in which they are listed.

You can read more about quality values in &PRODNAME; at
http://wiki.openrepose.org/display/REPOSE/Header+Value+Quality.
When set to true, match this validator to requests which do not pass an X-Roles header.

The X-Roles header can be set by the &PRODNAME; authentication component, assigning a role to a user. It is possible that, even after processing by the &PRODNAME; authentication component, a user might not be assigned a role.

You can read more about authentication in &PRODNAME; at
http://wiki.openrepose.org/display/REPOSE/Client+Authentication+Filter.

Only one validator can specify default="true". Marking more than one validator as default="true" is a severe error and will prevent &PRODNAME; from loading. In this example, in the validator labeled "VALIDATOR 1", you can see the validator identified as the default.

This attribute specifies the location of the WADL to be examined by this validator. If a relative path is specified, then this is a URI relative to the &PRODNAME; validation configuration, validator.cfg.xml. To validate a WADL outside the current file system, specify the URL of that WADL.
After the WADL is validated, if an incoming call is not found within the WADL the call is rejected with an appropriate error.
This attribute is optional.

If you do not use the wadl attribute to specify the location of an external WADL, you must embed a WADL within the validator element. In this example, in the validator labeled "VALIDATOR 3", you can see an embedded WADL beginning at <application>.

This attribute specifies the location of a visual representation to be generated by this validator, describing the validated WADL as a state machine in .dot format. This drawing is generated at &PRODNAME; startup; &PRODNAME; uses SHA-1 to determine whether the WADL has changed since startup. You can use this drawing to aid in debugging and optimizing the WADL. If a relative path is specified, then dot-output is a URI relative to the &PRODNAME; validation configuration, validator.cfg.xml. &PRODNAME; must have write access to the location specified by dot-output.
You can see examples of state-machine drawings, before and after API optimization, in the "Optimization" section of Using XProc, XSLT 2.0, and XSD 1.1 to validate RESTful services.

To see a .dot drawing generated to describe a WADL validated by your &PRODNAME; instance, use tools compatible with .dot format such as Inkscape http://inkscape.org/ or Graphviz http://www.graphviz.org/.
This attribute is optional.
When set to true, check-well-formed requires validation that the specified WADL's XML is well-formed.

When set to true, check-xsd-grammar requires validation that the specified WADL conforms to the XSD grammar specified within the WADL. In this example, in the validator labeled "VALIDATOR 3", you can see a grammar stylesheet specified within the embedded WADL.

When set to true, check-plain-params requires validation of plain parameters. These are grammar-agnostic assertions which can be used by non-XML media types. For example, although a WADL is defined with XML, JSONPath can be used to enable a WADL to describe a JSON-based API.

When set to true, enable-pre-process-extension enables the pre-process extension to the WADL. One use of this extension is to recognize ungrammatical elements and make them grammatical. For example, if only TRUE is strictly grammatical, the pre-process extension can recognize True and transform it to TRUE.
When set to true, remove-dups prevents duplicate nodes in the (state?) machine. When validation encounters a duplicate node, an unknown result occurs.
xpath-version specifies the XPath implementation used in validating the WADL.

listitem.para: When set to 1, xpath-version is the Xalan implementation.
When set to 2, xpath-version is the Saxon implementation. To use Saxon with schema awareness, you must have a Saxon license.

callout.para: When set to true, validate-checker runs pre-validation code to validate that the validator was generated correctly.
xsl-engine specifies the XSL 1.0 engine used in validating the WADL.

listitem.para: When set to Xalan, the Xalan engine is used.
When set to XalanC, the XalanC engine is used.
When set to Saxon, the Saxon engine is used. Saxon is an XSL 2.0 engine, but it works correctly with most 1.0 XSLs.

callout.para: When set to true, use-saxon requires use of Saxon-EE for XSD validation. Otherwise, the Xerces validator is used for XSD validation. To use Saxon for XSD validation, you must have a Saxon license.
When set to true, enable-ignore-xsd-extension enables use of the rax:ignoreXSD extension. This extension excludes some representations in WADLs from validation against the XSD.
When set to true, join-xpath-checks optimizes performance of the validator by merging the check-well-formed and multiple-XPath checks into a single check.
When set to true, join-check-headers requires validation of headers.

section.title: Customizing a Response Messaging Configuration
section.para:
If a request fails validation, then an appropriate HTTP response code is returned. For example:
If the validator determines that the URI is invalid, a 404 is returned.
If the validator determines that the URI is valid but the method is not appropriate for the URI, then a 405 is returned.
You can provide an appropriate error message along with the response code by configuring the response messaging service.

The &PRODNAME; API validation component processes invalid requests based on the response messaging configuration at response-messaging.cfg.xml. To change the response messaging configuration, edit response-messaging.cfg.xml at any time.

chapter.title: Deployment
chapter.para: The validation filter is packaged in the extensions filter bundle: extensions-filter-bundle-<version>.ear. When you initially deploy &PRODNAME;, your filter directory should contain filter-bundle-<version>.ear. Copy extensions-filter-bundle-<version>.ear to your filter directory; this directory should already contain filter-bundle-<version>.ear. Then update the filter chain in your system-model.cfg.xml to add <filter name="api-validator"/>.
Once validator.cfg.xml is in place, the EAR file is deployed, and the filter is added to the filter chain list, the filter will begin validating requests against the configured WADLs.

The validation filter is dependent upon third-party libraries. When running on a servlet container such as Tomcat or Glassfish, you should increase the servlet container's PermGen memory size to accommodate the additional libraries used by the validator. The ideal value depends upon your configuration; export JAVA_OPTS="$JAVA_OPTS -XX:MaxPermSize=256m" may be sufficient

chapter.title: Optimization
chapter.para: You can make choices in your validation configuration to optimize performance. You can use what you learn from the validator to improve the design of your API.

For ideas about using the &PRODNAME; API validation component to help with API optimization, which can help with performance, read the "Optimization" section of Using XProc, XSLT 2.0, and XSD 1.1 to validate RESTful services at http://www.balisage.net/Proceedings/vol8/html/Williams01/BalisageVol8-Williams01.html.
